flightsim.simconnect
Class SimConnect

java.lang.Object
  flightsim.simconnect.SimConnect
All Implemented Interfaces:
SimConnectConstants
public class SimConnect
extends java.lang.Object
implements SimConnectConstants

SimConnect main communication class.

A note on protocol version

NB: does not deal with IP (4 or 6) protocol ! .
When using a simconnect instance, some constructors accepts a protocol version number. These version indicates the simconnect protocol to emulate when talking to the remote FSX. The different FSX updates included new features to the simconnect protocol & client library, but also broke backward compatibility when the simconnect client is newer than the remote Flight Simulator instance.
JSimconnect uses the version given to the constructor to emulate an older simconnect protocol client, thus allowing to connect to older FSX versions. Note that by default, the protocol number used is the most up to date, and consequently a VERSION_MISMATCH exception will be received upon connecting to older FSX version. As of jsimconnect 0.7, this protocol version is 0x4, corresponding to Pre-SP2/Acceleration XPack.
As of jsimconnect 0.7 the supported protocol numbers are :
  • 0x2 (RTM version). Note that 0x1 (possibly from fsx beta) is not supported
  • 0x3 (SP1).
  • 0x4 (SP2/Acceleration)
When specifying a protocol version to emulate, some functions will be inhibited as they may not be available in the current version. For instance modeless UI, see text(int, float, int, String) are not available before SP1. Constructing a simconnect instance emulating protocol 0x2 will systematically throw a UnsupportedOperationException exception when calling this methods.

public SimConnect(java.lang.String appName)
           throws java.io.IOException
Open a simconnect connection to the local machine, guessing the right connection parameters. Port number, protocol and host are automatically guessed.
The most recent simconnect protocol version is used. Take care if you want backward compatiblity.

addToDataDefinition

public void addToDataDefinition(int dataDefinitionId,
                                java.lang.String datumName,
                                java.lang.String unitsName,
                                SimConnectDataType dataType,
                                float epsilon,
                                int datumId)
                         throws java.io.IOException
The addToDataDefinition method is used to add a Flight Simulator simulation variable name to a client defined object definition.

A data definition must be specified, using this function, before this function can be called If the data definition exceeds the size of the client data area on the server, then the extra bytes will be filled with zeros, an error will not be returned.

The data will be returned in a RecvSimObjectData structure.

Parameters:
dataDefinitionId - Specifies the ID of the client defined data definition.
datumName - Specifies the name of the Flight Simulator simulation variable. See the Simulation Variables document for a table of variable names. If an index is required then it should be appended to the variable name following a colon. Indexes are numbered from 1 (not zero). Simulation variable names are not case-sensitive (so can be entered in upper or lower case).
unitsName - Specifies the units of the variable. See the Simulation Variables document for a table of acceptable unit names. It is possible to specify different units to receive the data in, from those specified in the Simulation Variables document. The alternative units must come under the same heading (such as Angular Velocity, or Volume, as specified in the Units of Measurement section of the Simulation Variables document). For strings and structures enter null" for this parameter.
dataType - One member of the SimConnectDataType enumeration type. This parameter is used to determine what datatype should be used to return the data. The default is SimConnectDataType.FLOAT64. Note that the structure data types are legitimate parameters here.
epsilon - If data is requested only when it changes (see the flags parameter of requestDataOnSimObject(int, int, int, SimConnectPeriod, int, int, int, int), a change will only be reported if it is greater than the value of this parameter. The default is zero, so even the tiniest change will initiate the transmission of data. Set this value appropriately so insignificant changes are not transmitted. This can be used with integer data.
datumId - Specifies a client defined datum ID. The default is zero. Use this to identify the data received if the data is being returned in tagged format (see the flags parameter of requestDataOnSimObject(int, int, int, SimConnectPeriod, int, int, int, int)). There is no need to specify datum IDs if the data is not being returned in tagged format.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
clearDataDefinition(int), requestDataOnSimObject(int, int, int, SimConnectPeriod, int, int, int, int), requestDataOnSimObjectType(int, int, int, SimObjectType)

requestDataOnSimObject

public void requestDataOnSimObject(int dataRequestId,
                                   int dataDefinitionId,
                                   int objectId,
                                   SimConnectPeriod period,
                                   int flags,
                                   int origin,
                                   int interval,
                                   int limit)
                            throws java.io.IOException
The requestDataOnSimObject method is used to request when the SimConnect client is to receive data values for a specific object.

Changing the Period parameter or changing the content of a data definition has a higher performance cost than changing the origin, interval or limit parameters. So to termporarily turn off data requests, especially for short periods of time, consider setting the interval parameter to a very high value (such as DWORD _MAX). If changes are required to a data definition, consider setting the Period parameter to SimConnectPeriod.NEVER before making the changes, and then turning on the appropriate period after the changes have been made.

Data is always transmitted with the requestDataOnSimObject function, so if timing only notifications are required, use the subscribeToSystemEvent(int, String) function.

Note that variable length strings should not be used in data defintions, except where the Period parameter has been set to SimConnectPeriod.ONCE.

One method of testing whether the user has changed aircraft type is to use this function to return the title of the user aircraft, and note that if it changes, the user has changed the type of aircraft (all aircraft types have uniques title strings, including those simply with different color schemes).

Parameters:
dataRequestId - Specifies the ID of the client defined request. This is used later by the client to identify which data has been received. This value should be unique for each request, re-using a RequestID will overwrite any previous request using the same ID.
dataDefinitionId - Specifies the ID of the client defined data definition.
objectId - Specifies the ID of the Flight Simulator object that the data should be about. This ID can be SimConnectConstants.OBJECT_ID_USER (to specify the user's aircraft) or obtained from a RecvSimObjectDataByType structure after a call to requestDataOnSimObjectType(int, int, int, SimObjectType)
period - One member of the SimConnectPeriod enumeration type, specifying how often the data is to be sent by the server and recieved by the client.
flags - If 0, The default, data will be sent strictly according to the defined period. otherwise, see SimConnectConstants.DATA_REQUEST_FLAG_CHANGED or SimConnectConstants.DATA_REQUEST_FLAG_TAGGED
origin - The number of Period events that should elapse before transmission of the data begins. The default is zero, which means transmissions will start immediately.
interval - The number of Period events that should elapse between transmissions of the data. The default is zero, which means the data is transmitted every Period
limit - The number of times the data should be transmitted before this communication is ended. The default is zero, which means the data should be transmitted endlessly.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
addToDataDefinition(int, String, String, SimConnectDataType, float, int), clearDataDefinition(int)

requestDataOnSimObjectType

public void requestDataOnSimObjectType(int dataRequestId,
                                       int dataDefinitionId,
                                       int radiusMeters,
                                       SimObjectType type)
                                throws java.io.IOException
The requestDataOnSimObjectType function is used to retrieve informtion about simulation objects of a given type that are within a specifed radius of the user's aircraft.

The data will be returned on all the relevant objects within the specified radius, but they will not be returned in any specific order. It is the responsibility of the client program to sort the returned data into order, if that is required. Information is returned in a RecvSimObjectDataByType structure, one structure per object.

Parameters:
dataRequestId - Specifies the ID of the client defined request. This is used later by the client to identify which data has been received. This value should be unique for each request, re-using a RequestID will overwrite any previous request using the same ID.
dataDefinitionId - Specifies the ID of the client defined data definition.
radiusMeters - Double word containing the radius in meters. If this is set to zero then information on all relevant objects will be returned. This value is ignored if type is set to SimObjectType.USER. The error SimConnectException.OUT_OF_BOUNDS will be returned if a radius is given and it exceeds the maximum allowed (200 Km).
type - Specifies the type of object to receive information on. One member of the SimObjectType.USER enumeration type.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
addToDataDefinition(int, String, String, SimConnectDataType, float, int), requestDataOnSimObject(int, int, int, SimConnectPeriod, int, int, int, int)

                                       SimObjectType type)

                                   java.lang.String eventName)
                            throws java.io.IOException

Notifications of the events are returned in a RecvEvent structure or one of its subclasses

eventName - The string name for the requested system event

unsubscribeFromSystemEvent

public void unsubscribeFromSystemEvent(int clientEventID)
                                throws java.io.IOException
The unsubscribeFromSystemEvent method is used to request that notifications are no longer received for the specified system event.

There is no limit to the number of system events that can be subscribed to, but use this function to improve performance when a system event notification is no longer needed.

Parameters:
clientEventID - Specifies the client-defined event ID.
Throws:
java.io.IOException

requestSystemState

public void requestSystemState(int dataRequestID,
                               java.lang.String state)
                        throws java.io.IOException
The requestSystemState function is used to request information from a number of Flight Simulator system components.

The information requested will be returned in a RecvSystemState structure.

List of system events :

String Description
AircraftLoaded Requests the full path name of the last loaded aircraft flight dynamics file. These files have a .AIR extension.
DialogMode Requests whether the simulation is in Dialog mode or not. See setSystemState(String, int, float, String) for a description of Dialog mode.
FlightLoaded Requests the full path name of the last loaded flight. Flight files have the extension .FLT.
FlightPlan Requests the full path name of the active flight plan. An empty string will be returned if there is no active flight plan.
Sim Requests the state of the simulation. If 1 is returned, the user is in control of the aircraft, if 0 is returned, the user is navigating the UI. This is the same state that notifications can be subscribed to with the SimStart and SimStop string with the subscribeToSystemEvent(int, String) function.

Parameters:
dataRequestID - The client defined request ID.
state - A string identifying the system function.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
setSystemState(String, int, float, String)

requestSystemState

public void requestSystemState(java.lang.Enum dataRequestID,
                               java.lang.String state)
                        throws java.io.IOException
The requestSystemState function is used to request information from a number of Flight Simulator system components.

The information requested will be returned in a RecvSystemState structure.

List of system events :

String Description
AircraftLoaded Requests the full path name of the last loaded aircraft flight dynamics file. These files have a .AIR extension.
DialogMode Requests whether the simulation is in Dialog mode or not. See setSystemState(String, int, float, String) for a description of Dialog mode.
FlightLoaded Requests the full path name of the last loaded flight. Flight files have the extension .FLT.
FlightPlan Requests the full path name of the active flight plan. An empty string will be returned if there is no active flight plan.
Sim Requests the state of the simulation. If 1 is returned, the user is in control of the aircraft, if 0 is returned, the user is navigating the UI. This is the same state that notifications can be subscribed to with the SimStart and SimStop string with the subscribeToSystemEvent(int, String) function.

Parameters:
dataRequestID - The client defined request ID.
state - A string identifying the system function.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
Since:
0.4
See Also:

                           int paramInt,
                           float paramFloat,
                           java.lang.String paramString)
                    throws java.io.IOException

The integer, float and string set with this function match those in the RecvSystemState structure (which is returned if the information is requested with the requestSystemState(int, String) call.

paramInt - An integer value, set depending on the value of state (not currently used).

addClientEventToNotificationGroup

public void addClientEventToNotificationGroup(int notificationGroupID,
                                              int clientEventID,
                                              boolean maskable)
                                       throws java.io.IOException
The addClientEventToNotificationGroup function is used to add an individual client defined event to a notification group.

The maximum number of events that can be added to a notfication group is 1000. A notification group is simply a convenient way of setting the appropriate priority for a range of events, and all client events must be assigned to a notification group before any event notifications will be received from the SimConnect server.

Parameters:
notificationGroupID - Specifies the ID of the client defined group.
clientEventID - Specifies the ID of the client defined event.
maskable - Boolean, true indicates that the event will be masked by this client and will not be transmitted to any more clients, possibly including Flight Simulator itself (if the priority of the client exceeds that of Flight Simulator). False is the default. See the explanation of NotificationPriority.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
removeClientEvent(int, int), setNotificationGroupPriority(int, NotificationPriority), clearNotificationGroup(int)

addClientEventToNotificationGroup

public void addClientEventToNotificationGroup(java.lang.Enum notificationGroupID,
                                              java.lang.Enum clientEventID,
                                              boolean maskable)
                                       throws java.io.IOException

clientEventID - Specifies the ID of the client defined event.

False is the default. See the explanation of NotificationPriority.

mapClientEventToSimEvent

public void mapClientEventToSimEvent(int clientEventId)
                              throws java.io.IOException
The mapClientEventToSimEvent method associates a client defined event ID with a Flight Simulator event name.

Client events must be added to a group event (to set the appropriate priority) before event notifications will be received from the SimConnect server (see the addClientEventToNotificationGroup(int, int, boolean) function).

Parameters:
clientEventId - Specifies the ID of the client event.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
addClientEventToNotificationGroup(int, int, boolean), transmitClientEvent(int, int, int, int, int)

mapClientEventToSimEvent

                              throws java.io.IOException

mapClientEventToSimEvent

public void mapClientEventToSimEvent(int clientEventId,
                                     java.lang.String eventName)
                              throws java.io.IOException
The mapClientEventToSimEvent method associates a client defined event ID with a Flight Simulator event name.

Client events must be added to a group event (to set the appropriate priority) before event notifications will be received from the SimConnect server (see the addClientEventToNotificationGroup(int, int, boolean) function).

Parameters:
clientEventId - Specifies the ID of the client event.
eventName - Specifies the Flight Simulator event name. Refer to the Event IDs document for a list of event names (listed under SimConnect Name). If the event name includes one or more periods (such as "Client.Event" in the example below) then they are custom events specified by the client, and will only be recognised by another client (and not Flight Simulator) that has been coded to receive such events. No Flight Simulator events include periods. If no entry is made for this parameter, the event is private to the client.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
addClientEventToNotificationGroup(int, int, boolean), transmitClientEvent(int, int, int, int, int)

Throws:
java.io.IOException
Since:
0.4
See Also:

transmitClientEvent

public void transmitClientEvent(int objectID,
                                int eventID,
                                int data,
                                int groupID,
                                int flags)
                         throws java.io.IOException
The transmitClientEvent function is used to request that the Flight Simulator server transmit to all SimConnect clients the specified client event.

Typically use this function to transmit an event to other SimConnect clients, including the simulation engine of Flight Simulator, although the client that transmits the event can also receive it. The order in which client notification groups are informed of the event is determined by the priority of each group. The higher the priority of the group, the earlier it will receive the event notification. Refer to the explanation of the maskable parameter for the addClientEventToNotificationGroup(int, int, boolean) call, which describes when the event may be masked and not transmitted to lower priority groups. Also see the explanation of NotificationPriority.

Parameters:
objectID - Specifies the ID of the server defined object. If this parameter is set to SimConnectConstants.OBJECT_ID_USER, then the transmitted event will be sent to the other clients in priority order. If this parameters contains another object ID, then the event will be sent direct to that sim-object, and no other clients will receive it.
eventID - Specifies the ID of the client event.
data - integer containing any additional number required by the event. This is often zero. If the event is a Flight Simulator event, then refer to the Event IDs document for information on this additional value. If the event is a custom event, then any value put in this parameter will be available to the clients that receive the event.
groupID - The default behavior is that this specifies the GroupID of the event. The SimConnect server will use the priority of this group to send the messasge to all clients with a lower priority. To receive the event notification other SimConnect clients must have subscribed to receive the event. See the explanation of NotificationPriority. The exception to the default behaviour is set by the SimConnectConstants.EVENT_FLAG_GROUPID_IS_PRIORITY flag
flags - One of the following flags : SimConnectConstants.EVENT_FLAG_DEFAULT, SimConnectConstants.EVENT_FLAG_FAST_REPEAT_TIMER, SimConnectConstants.EVENT_FLAG_GROUPID_IS_PRIORITY, SimConnectConstants.EVENT_FLAG_SLOW_REPEAT_TIMER
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
mapClientEventToSimEvent(int, String)

transmitClientEvent

public void transmitClientEvent(int objectID,
                                java.lang.Enum eventID,
                                int data,
                                java.lang.Enum groupID,
                                int flags)
                         throws java.io.IOException

setSystemEventState

public void setSystemEventState(int eventID,
                                boolean state)
                         throws java.io.IOException
The setSystemEventState function is used to turn requests for event information from the server on and off.

If this function is not called, the default is for the state to be on. This is different from input events, which have a default state of off.

Use this function to turn system events temporarily on and off, rather than make multiple calls to subscribeToSystemEvent(int, String) and unsubscribeFromSystemEvent(int), which is less efficient

Parameters:
eventID - Specifies the ID of the client event that is to have its state changed.
state - true to activate
Throws:
java.io.IOException

setNotificationGroupPriority

public void setNotificationGroupPriority(int groupID,
                                         NotificationPriority priority)
                                  throws java.io.IOException
The setNotificationGroupPriority function is used to set the priority for a notification group.

NotificationPriority for a list of notification group priority. Each notifiction group has an assigned priority, and the SimConnect server will send events out strictly in the order of priority. No two groups will be set at the same priority. If a request is recieved for a group to be set at a priority that has already been taken, the group will be assigned the next lowest priority that is available. This includes groups from all the clients that have opened communications with the server.

If a group has an assigned priority above NotificationPriority.HIGHEST_MASKABLE then it cannot mask events (hide them from other clients). If the group has a priority equal to or below NotificationPriority.HIGHEST_MASKABLE , then events can be masked (the maskable flag must be set by the addClientEventToNotificationGroup(int, int, boolean) function to do this). Note that it is possible to mask Flight Simulator events, and therefore intercept them before they reach the simulation engine, and perhaps send new events to the simulation engine after appropriate processing has been done. Flight Simulator's simulation engine is treated as as SimConnect client in this regard, with a priority of NotificationPriority.DEFAULT.

Input group events work in a similar manner. The priority groups are not combined though, a group and an input group can both have the same priority number. The SimConnect server manages two lists: notification groups and input groups.

A typical use of masking is to prevent Flight Simulator itself from receiving an event, in order for the SimConnect client to completely replace the fucntionality in this case. Another use of masking is with co-operative clients, where there are multiple versions (perhaps a deluxe and standard version, or later and earlier versions), where the deluxe or later version might need to mask events from the other client, if they are both up and running. Flight Simulator does not mask any events. p

Parameters:
groupID - Specifies the ID of the client defined group.
priority - Requests the group's priority
Throws:
java.io.IOException

setNotificationGroupPriority

public void setNotificationGroupPriority(java.lang.Enum groupID,
                                         NotificationPriority priority)
                                  throws java.io.IOException
The setNotificationGroupPriority function is used to set the priority for a notification group.

clearNotificationGroup

public void clearNotificationGroup(int groupID)
                            throws java.io.IOException
Remove all the client defined events from a notification group.

Remark There is a maximum of 20 notification groups in any SimConnect client. Use this function if the maximum has been reached, but one or more are not longer required.

setDataOnSimObject

public void setDataOnSimObject(int dataDefinitionID,
                               int objectID,
                               boolean tagged,
                               int arrayCount,
                               byte[] data)
                        throws java.io.IOException
The setDataOnSimObject function is used to make changes to the data properties of an object.

The data that is set on an object is defined in a data definition (see addToDataDefinition(int, String, String, SimConnectDataType)). This data can include the following structures: Waypoint, InitPosition and MarkerState. Any number of waypoints can be given to an AI object using a single call to this function, and any number of marker state structures can also be combined into an array.

The Simulation Variables document includes a column indicating whether variables can be written to or not. An exception will be returned if an attempt is made to write to a variable that cannot be set in this way.

Parameters:
dataDefinitionID - Specifies the ID of the client defined data definition.
objectID - Specifies the ID of the Flight Simulator object that the data should be about. This ID can be SIMCONNECT_OBJECT_ID_USER (to specify the user's aircraft) or obtained from a SIMCONNECT_RECV_SIMOBJECT_DATA_BYTYPE structure after a call to SimConnect_RequestDataOnSimObjectType.
tagged - The data to be set is being sent in tagged format. Refer to SimConnect_RequestDataOnSimObject for more details on the tagged format.
arrayCount - Specifies the number of elements in the data array. A count of zero is interpreted as one element.
data - data array
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
addToDataDefinition(int, String, String, SimConnectDataType), clearDataDefinition(int), requestDataOnSimObject(int, int, int, SimConnectPeriod), requestDataOnSimObjectType(int, int, int, SimObjectType)

                               byte[] data)

                               int objectID,
                               double... data)
                        throws java.io.IOException

objectID - Specifies the ID of the Flight Simulator object that the data should be about. This ID can be SIMCONNECT_OBJECT_ID_USER (to specify the user's aircraft) or obtained from a SIMCONNECT_RECV_SIMOBJECT_DATA_BYTYPE structure after a call to SimConnect_RequestDataOnSimObjectType.

setDataOnSimObject

public void setDataOnSimObject(java.lang.Enum dataDefinitionID,
                               int objectID,
                               SimConnectData[] data)
                        throws java.io.IOException
The setDataOnSimObject function is used to make changes to the data properties of an object.

The data that is set on an object is defined in a data definition (see addToDataDefinition(int, String, String, SimConnectDataType)). This data can include the following structures: Waypoint, InitPosition and MarkerState. Any number of waypoints can be given to an AI object using a single call to this function, and any number of marker state structures can also be combined into an array.

The Simulation Variables document includes a column indicating whether variables can be written to or not. An exception will be returned if an attempt is made to write to a variable that cannot be set in this way.

Parameters:
dataDefinitionID - Specifies the ID of the client defined data definition.
objectID - Specifies the ID of the Flight Simulator object that the data should be about. This ID can be SIMCONNECT_OBJECT_ID_USER (to specify the user's aircraft) or obtained from a SIMCONNECT_RECV_SIMOBJECT_DATA_BYTYPE structure after a call to SimConnect_RequestDataOnSimObjectType.
data - Array of SimConnectData structures suitable for writing
Throws:
java.io.IOException
Since:
0.4
See Also:
addToDataDefinition(int, String, String, SimConnectDataType), clearDataDefinition(int), requestDataOnSimObject(int, int, int, SimConnectPeriod), requestDataOnSimObjectType(int, int, int, SimObjectType)

setDataOnSimObject

public void setDataOnSimObject(int dataDefinitionID,
                               int objectID,
                               boolean tagged,
                               int arrayCount,
                               DataWrapper data)
                        throws java.io.IOException
The setDataOnSimObject function is used to make changes to the data properties of an object.

The data that is set on an object is defined in a data definition (see addToDataDefinition(int, String, String, SimConnectDataType)). This data can include the following structures: Waypoint, InitPosition and MarkerState. Any number of waypoints can be given to an AI object using a single call to this function, and any number of marker state structures can also be combined into an array.

The Simulation Variables document includes a column indicating whether variables can be written to or not. An exception will be returned if an attempt is made to write to a variable that cannot be set in this way.

Parameters:
dataDefinitionID - Specifies the ID of the client defined data definition.
objectID - Specifies the ID of the Flight Simulator object that the data should be about. This ID can be SIMCONNECT_OBJECT_ID_USER (to specify the user's aircraft) or obtained from a SIMCONNECT_RECV_SIMOBJECT_DATA_BYTYPE structure after a call to SimConnect_RequestDataOnSimObjectType.
tagged - The data to be set is being sent in tagged format. Refer to SimConnect_RequestDataOnSimObject for more details on the tagged format.
arrayCount - Specifies the number of elements in the data array. A count of zero is interpreted as one element.
data - DataWrapper containing the data to write
Throws:
java.io.IOException
Since:

mapInputEventToClientEvent

public void mapInputEventToClientEvent(int inputGroupID,
                                       java.lang.String inputDefinition,
                                       int clientEventDownID)
                                throws java.io.IOException
The mapInputEventToClientEvent function is used to connect input events (such as keystrokes, joystick or mouse movements) with the sending of appropriate event notifications.

The maximum number of events that can be added to an input group is 1000.

For the keyboard the input definition can include a maximum of two modifiers (Shift, Ctrl, Alt) and two keys (case senstive).

For joysticks the input definition is in the form 

"joystick:n:input[:i]".
Where n is the joystick number (starting from 0), input is the input name, and i is an optional index number that might be required by the input name (
joystick:0:button:0
for example).

Parameters:
inputGroupID - Specifies the ID of the client defined input group that the input event is to be added to.
inputDefinition - string containing the definition of the input events (keyboard keys, mouse or joystick events, for example).
clientEventDownID - Specifies the ID of the down, and default, event. This is the client defined event that is triggered when the input event occurs. If only an up event is required, set this to SimConnectConstants.UNUSED.
Throws:
java.io.IOException

mapInputEventToClientEvent

public void mapInputEventToClientEvent(java.lang.Enum inputGroupID,
                                       java.lang.String inputDefinition,
                                       java.lang.Enum clientEventDownID)
                                throws java.io.IOException

mapInputEventToClientEvent

public void mapInputEventToClientEvent(int inputGroupID,
                                       java.lang.String inputDefinition,
                                       int clientEventDownID,
                                       int downValue,
                                       int clientEventUpID,
                                       int UpValue,
                                       boolean maskable)
                                throws java.io.IOException
The mapInputEventToClientEvent function is used to connect input events (such as keystrokes, joystick or mouse movements) with the sending of appropriate event notifications.

The maximum number of events that can be added to an input group is 1000.

For the keyboard the input definition can include a maximum of two modifiers (Shift, Ctrl, Alt) and two keys (case senstive).

For joysticks the input definition is in the form 

"joystick:n:input[:i]".
Where n is the joystick number (starting from 0), input is the input name, and i is an optional index number that might be required by the input name (
joystick:0:button:0
for example).

Parameters:
inputGroupID - Specifies the ID of the client defined input group that the input event is to be added to.
inputDefinition - string containing the definition of the input events (keyboard keys, mouse or joystick events, for example).
clientEventDownID - Specifies the ID of the down, and default, event. This is the client defined event that is triggered when the input event occurs. If only an up event is required, set this to SimConnectConstants.UNUSED.
downValue - Specifies an optional numeric value, which will be returned when the down event occurs.
clientEventUpID - Specifies the ID of the up event. This is the client defined event that is triggered when the up action occurs.
UpValue - Specifies an optional numeric value, which will be returned when the up event occurs.
maskable - If set to true, specifies that the client will mask the event, and no other lower priority clients will receive it.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
removeInputEvent(int, String), clearInputGroup(int), setInputGroupPriority(int, NotificationPriority)

downValue - Specifies an optional numeric value, which will be returned when the down event occurs.

removeInputEvent

public void removeInputEvent(int inputGroupID,
                             java.lang.String inputDefinition)
                      throws java.io.IOException
The removeInputEvent method is used to remove an input event from a specified input group object.

The input string definitions must match exactly, before anything is removed from the group definition. For example, the string defintiions "A+B" and "a+B" do not match.

Parameters:
inputGroupID - Specifies the ID of the client defined input group from which the event is to be removed.
inputDefinition - string containing the input definition.
Throws:
java.io.IOException

clearInputGroup

public void clearInputGroup(int inputGroupID)
                     throws java.io.IOException
The clearInputGroup method is used to remove all the input events from a specified input group object.

Use this function to permanently delete an input group. Use the setInputGroupState(int, boolean) method to temporarily suspend input group notifications .

Parameters:
inputGroupID - Specifies the ID of the client defined input group that is to have all its events removed.
Throws:
java.io.IOException

                               boolean state)
                        throws java.io.IOException

requestReservedKey

public void requestReservedKey(int eventID,
                               java.lang.String keyChoice1)
                        throws java.io.IOException
The requestReservedKey method is used to request a specific keyboard TAB-key combination applies only to this client.

A successful call to this function will result in a RecvReservedKey class being returned, with the key that has been assigned to this client. The first of the three that can be assigned will be the choice, unless all three are already taken, in which case a null string will be returned.

The keyChoice parameters should be a single character (such as "A"), which is requesting that the key combination TAB-A is reserved for this client. All reserved keys are TAB-key combinations.

Parameters:
eventID - Specifies the client defined event ID.
keyChoice1 - string containing the first key choice. Refer to the document Key Strings for a full list of choices that can be entered for these three
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
menuAddItem(String, int, int)

keyChoice2 - string containing the second key choice.

weatherRequestInterpolatedObservation

public void weatherRequestInterpolatedObservation(int dataRequestID,
                                                  float lat,
                                                  float lon,
                                                  float alt)
                                           throws java.io.IOException
The weatherRequestInterpolatedObservation method is used to send a request for weather data that is interpolated from the weather at the nearest three weather stations.

The weather data will be returned in a RecvWeatherObservation structure. A number of errors apply specifically to weather data, see the RecvException enumeration.

Interpolated weather data can be used to identify suitable locations for thermals and other local weather systems. The process of using the three nearest stations is not without its drawbacks, as all three stations could be in one direction of the specified point, and not a reasonable spread in different directions. Weather data is returned in Metar data format.

Parameters:
dataRequestID - Specifies the ID of the client defined request. This is used later by the client to identify which data has been received.
lat - Specifies latitude in degrees.
lon - Specifies longitude in degrees.
alt - Specifies altitude in feet above sea level. This differs from most weather data altitudes, which are feet above ground level.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
weatherSetObservation(int, String), weatherSetModeServer(int, int), weatherRequestObservationAtStation(int, String), weatherRequestObservationAtNearestStation(int, float, float)

weatherRequestObservationAtStation

public void weatherRequestObservationAtStation(int dataRequestID,
                                               java.lang.String ICAO)
                                        throws java.io.IOException
The weatherRequestObservationAtStation method requests the weather data from a weather station identified by its ICAO code.

The weather data will be returned in a RecvWeatherObservation structure. A number of errors apply specifically to weather data, see the RecvException enumeration. Weather data is returned in Metar data format.

Parameters:
dataRequestID - Specifies the ID of the client defined request. This is used later by the client to identify which data has been received.
ICAO - string specifyin the ICAO identification code of the weather station. Typically this is an airport. Set to GLOB to retrieve global weather.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
weatherRequestObservationAtNearestStation(int, float, float), weatherRequestInterpolatedObservation(int, float, float, float), weatherSetObservation(int, String), weatherSetModeServer(int, int)

                                                      float lat,
                                                      float lon)
                                               throws java.io.IOException

Parameters:
dataRequestID - Specifies the ID of the client defined request. This is used later by the client to identify which data has been received
lat - Specifies latitude in degrees.
lon - Specifies longitude in degrees.
Throws:
java.io.IOException

weatherCreateStation

public void weatherCreateStation(int dataRequestID,
                                 java.lang.String ICAO,
                                 java.lang.String name,
                                 float lat,
                                 float lon,
                                 float alt)
                          throws java.io.IOException
The weatherCreateStation method creates a weather station at the given ICAO location.

If an attempt is made to create a weather station at an airport that already has one, the error SimConnectException.WEATHER_UNABLE_TO_CREATE_STATION will be returned.

Once a weather station has been successfully created, its weather output can be set with a call to weatherSetObservation(int, String), and retrieved with a call to weatherRequestObservationAtStation(int, String).

Parameters:
dataRequestID - Specifies the client defined request ID.
ICAO - Specifies the ICAO string. This can be an existing airport ICAO string, as long as the airport does not already have a weather station, or it can be a unique new ICAO code to be used just for the purposes of this weather station.
name - Specifies a descriptive name for the new weather station. This name will appear on the weather map in the weather dialogs of Flight Simulator.
lat - Specifies the latitude of the station in degrees. The latitude, longitude and altitude parameters should be set to 0 if the ICAO code supplied is from an existing airport.
lon - Specifies the longitude of the station in degrees.
alt - Specifies the altitude of the station in feet, above ground level.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
weatherRemoveStation(int, String)

weatherRemoveStation

public void weatherRemoveStation(int dataRequestID,
                                 java.lang.String ICAO)
                          throws java.io.IOException
The weatherRemoveStation method requests that the weather station identified by the given ICAO string is removed.

If a call is made to remove a weather station created by another client, or an exiting one within Flight Simulator, the error SimConnectException.WEATHER_UNABLE_TO_REMOVE_STATION will be returned.

If the client is closed, then all weather stations created by the client will be removed.

Parameters:
dataRequestID - Specifies the client defined request ID.
ICAO - Specifies the ICAO string of the station to remove. The station must be one that was created by the same SimConnect client.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
weatherCreateStation(int, String, String, float, float, float)

weatherSetObservation

public void weatherSetObservation(int seconds,
                                  java.lang.String metar)
                           throws java.io.IOException
The weatherSetObservation method is used to set the weather at a specific weather station, identified from within the Metar data string.

A number of errors apply specifically to weather data, see the RecvException enumeration.

Parameters:
seconds - Specifies the time in seconds that the current weather should merge into the new weather
metar - string containing the METAR data.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
weatherRequestInterpolatedObservation(int, float, float, float), weatherRequestObservationAtNearestStation(int, float, float), weatherRequestObservationAtStation(int, String), weatherSetModeServer(int, int)

weatherSetModeServer

public void weatherSetModeServer(int port,
                                 int seconds)
                          throws java.io.IOException
The weatherSetModeServer method is used to switch to a local server for weather observation data.

Calling this function sets the weather mode to "Real-world weather " in the Weather dialog of Flight Simulator X. The Weather dialog only allows two update rates (none and 15 minutes), whereas this call gives much greater flexibility over the update rate. Setting the port number allows a local weather server to be used, rather than the default.

A number of errors apply specifically to weather data, see the RecvException enumeration.

Parameters:
port - the port number of the weather server. Set this to zero to reset the weather to normal operation.
seconds - the amount of time, in seconds, that should elapse between each update. There is a minimum of 60 seconds.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
weatherSetModeCustom(), weatherSetModeGlobal(), weatherSetModeCustom()

weatherSetModeTheme

public void weatherSetModeTheme(java.lang.String themeName)
                         throws java.io.IOException
The weatherSetModeTheme method is used to set the weather to a particular theme.

Calling this function sets the weather mode to "Weather themes " in the weather dialog of Flight Simulator X.

There are three files associated with a weather theme in Flight Simulator X, for example: grayrain.wt, grayrain.bmp and grayrain.wtb. The wt file contains the description that will appear in the Current Conditions box in the Weather dialog, the bmp file contains the image that will also appear in the weather dialog, and the wtb file contains data in a propriety format that contains the weather information.

Parameters:
themeName - string containing the theme filename. The corresponding files should exist in the Microsoft Flight Simulator X/weather/themes folder. For example, enter "grayrain" to set the same theme as if the user had selected Gray and Rainy from the Weather dialog.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
weatherSetModeCustom(), weatherSetModeGlobal(), weatherSetModeServer(int, int)

weatherSetModeGlobal

public void weatherSetModeGlobal()
                          throws java.io.IOException
The weatherSetModeGlobal method sets the weather mode to global, so the same weather data is used everywhere.

There is not an equivalent setting in the weather dialog of Flight Simulator X.

Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
weatherSetModeCustom(), weatherSetModeServer(int, int), weatherSetModeTheme(String)

weatherSetModeCustom

public void weatherSetModeCustom()
                          throws java.io.IOException
The weatherSetModeCustom method sets the weather mode to user-defined.

Calling this function sets the weather mode to "User-defined weather" in the Weather dialog of Flight Simulator X, so whatever the user has entered for the weather will be used.

Throws:
java.io.IOException

weatherSetDynamicUpdateRate

public void weatherSetDynamicUpdateRate(int rate)
                                 throws java.io.IOException
The weatherSetDynamicUpdateRate function is used to set the rate at which cloud formations change.

Parameters:
rate - Integer containing the rate. A value of zero indicates that cloud formations do not change at all. Values between 1 and 5 indicate that cloud formations should change from 1 (the slowest) to 5 (the fastest). These settings match those than can be set through the dialogs of Flight Simulator X.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
weatherSetModeCustom(), weatherSetModeServer(int, int), weatherSetModeTheme(String), weatherSetModeGlobal()

weatherRequestCloudState

public void weatherRequestCloudState(int dataRequestID,
                                     float minLat,
                                     float minLon,
                                     float minAlt,
                                     float maxLat,
                                     float maxLon,
                                     float maxAlt,
                                     int flags)
                              throws java.io.IOException
The weatherRequestCloudState method requests cloud density information on a given area.

The main purpose of this function is to enable weather radar. If the call is successful, the cloud state information will be returned in a RecvCloudState structure. This structure will contain a two dimensional array of byte data. The array will be 64 x 64 bytes in size, and each byte will contain a value indicating the cloud density for each cell. A value of zero would mean no clouds, to a maximum of 255. The area defined in this call is divided into 64 by 64 cells, so the size of each cell will be determined by the values given for the parameters above. Note that the entire World's weather is not simulated all the time, but only a region around the user aircraf, with a radius of approximately 128 kilometers, is modeled at any one time. A request for cloud data outside this region will simply return zeros.

The defined area can cross the Equator or the Greenwich Meridian, but it cannot cross the Poles or the International Date Line.

Parameters:
dataRequestID - Specifies the client-defined request ID.
minLat - Specifies the minimum latitude of the required area. This should simply be the lower of the two latitude numbers.
minLon - Specifies the minimum longitude of the required area. This should simply be the lower of the two longitude numbers.
minAlt - Specifies the minimum altitude of the required area, in feet.
maxLat - Specifies the maximum latitude of the required area.
maxLon - Specifies the maximum longitude of the required area.
maxAlt - Specifies the maximum altitude of the required area, in feet.
flags - Reserved for future use.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
weatherSetModeCustom(), weatherSetModeServer(int, int), weatherSetModeTheme(String), weatherSetModeGlobal(), weatherSetDynamicUpdateRate(int)

weatherRequestCloudState

                                     float minAlt,
                                     float maxLat,

weatherCreateThermal

public void weatherCreateThermal(int dataRequestID,
                                 float lat,
                                 float lon,
                                 float alt,
                                 float radius,
                                 float height)
                          throws java.io.IOException
The weatherCreateThermal method is used to create a thermal at a specific location. The method is filled with default parameters. (3.0, 0.05, 3.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.1, 0.4, 0.1)

There is no limit to the number of thermals that can be created. Within the simulator a thermal is defined as a cylinder with a Core layer and a Sink layer

Parameters:
dataRequestID - Specifies the client defined request ID.
lat - Specifies the latitude of the thermal in degrees.
lon - Specifies the longitude of the thermal in degrees.
alt - Specifies the altitude of the thermal in feet, above ground level.
radius - Specifies the radius of the thermal, in meters. The maximum radius of a thermal is 100Km.
height - Specifies the height of the thermal, in meters.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
weatherCreateThermal(int, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float), weatherRemoveThermal(int)

weatherCreateThermal

public void weatherCreateThermal(int dataRequestID,
                                 float lat,
                                 float lon,
                                 float alt,
                                 float radius,
                                 float height,
                                 float coreRate,
                                 float coreTurbulence,
                                 float sinkRate,
                                 float sinkTurbulence,
                                 float coreSize,
                                 float coreTransitionSize,
                                 float sinkLayerSize,
                                 float sinkTransitionSize)
                          throws java.io.IOException
The weatherCreateThermal method is used to create a thermal at a specific location.

There is no limit to the number of thermals that can be created. Within the simulator a thermal is defined as a cylinder with a Core layer and a Sink layer

Parameters:
dataRequestID - Specifies the client defined request ID.
lat - Specifies the latitude of the thermal in degrees.
lon - Specifies the longitude of the thermal in degrees.
alt - Specifies the altitude of the thermal in feet, above ground level.
radius - Specifies the radius of the thermal, in meters. The maximum radius of a thermal is 100Km.
height - Specifies the height of the thermal, in meters.
coreRate - Specifies the lift value, in meters per second, within the Core layer. A positive value will provide an updraft, a negative value a downdraft. The maximum rate is 1000 meters/second.
coreTurbulence - Specifies a variation in meters per second that is applied to the coreRate. For example, if a value of 1.5 is entered, and the core rate is 5 m/s, the actual core rate applied will be randomly varying between 3.5 m/s and 6.5 m/s.
sinkRate - Specifies the lift value, in meters per second, within the Sink layer. A positive value will provide an updraft, a negative value a downdraft. The maximum rate is 1000 meters/second.
sinkTurbulence - Specifies a variation in meters per second that is applied to the sinkRate. For example, if a value of 1.5 is entered, and the sink rate is 5 m/s, the actual sink rate applied will be randomly varying between 3.5 m/s and 6.5 m/s.
coreSize - Specifies the radius in meters of the Core of the thermal.
coreTransitionSize - Specifies the width in meters of the transition layer between the Core and the Sink of the thermal. Half of the width of this transition will be outside the Core, and half within.
sinkLayerSize - Specifies the radius in meters of the Sink of the thermal.
sinkTransitionSize - Specifies the width in meters of the transition layer between the Sink and the atmosphere outside of the thermal. Half of the width of this transition will be outside the radius of the Sink layer, and half within.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
weatherRemoveThermal(int)

weatherRemoveThermal

public void weatherRemoveThermal(int objectID)
                          throws java.io.IOException
The weatherRemoveThermal method removes a thermal.

A client application can only remove thermals that it created, and not thermals created by other clients or by Flight Simulator. If the client is closed, then all thermals created by the client will be removed.

Parameters:
objectID - Specifies the object ID of the thermal to be removed.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
weatherCreateThermal(int, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float), weatherCreateThermal(int, float, float, float, float, float)

aICreateParkedATCAircraft

public void aICreateParkedATCAircraft(java.lang.String containerTitle,
                                      java.lang.String tailNumber,
                                      java.lang.String airportID,
                                      int dataRequestID)
                               throws java.io.IOException
The aICreateParkedATCAircraft function is used to create an AI controlled aircraft that is currently parked and does not have a flight plan.

Calling this function is no guarrantee that there is sufficient parking space at the specified airport. An error will be returned if there is insufficient parking space, and an aircraft will not be created. A number of errors, including SimConnectException.CREATE_OBJECT_FAILED, apply to AI objects (refer to the SimConnectException enum for more details). After creating an aircraft with this function, a call to aISetAircraftFlightPlan(int, String, int) will set the aircraft in motion. Refer to the remarks for aICreateEnrouteATCAircraft(String, String, int, String, double, boolean, int).

Parameters:
containerTitle - tring containing the container title. The container title is case-sensitive and can found in the aircraft.cfg file for example: title=Airbus A321, title= Aircreation582SL, or title=Boeing 737-800.
tailNumber - string containing the tail number. This should have a maximum of 12 characters.
airportID - string containing the airport ID. This is the ICAO identification string, for example, KSEA for SeaTac International.
dataRequestID - Specifies the client defined request ID.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
aICreateEnrouteATCAircraft(String, String, int, String, double, boolean, int), aICreateNonATCAircraft(String, String, InitPosition, int), aICreateSimulatedObject(String, InitPosition, int), aIRemoveObject(int, int), aISetAircraftFlightPlan(int, String, int)

aICreateEnrouteATCAircraft

public void aICreateEnrouteATCAircraft(java.lang.String containerTitle,
                                       java.lang.String tailNumber,
                                       int flightNumber,
                                       java.lang.String flightPlanPath,
                                       double flightPlanPosition,
                                       boolean touchAndGo,
                                       int dataRequestID)
                                throws java.io.IOException
The aICreateEnrouteATCAircraft function is used to create an AI controlled aircraft that is about to start or is already underway on its flight plan.

An enroute aircraft can be on the ground or airborne when it is created by this function. Typically this will be an aircraft flying under IFR rules, and in constant radio contact with ATC. A number of errors, including SimConnectException.CREATE_OBJECT_FAILED, apply to AI objects (refer to the SimConnectException enum for more details).

A RecvEventAddRemove event notification can be subscribed to (see the subscribeToSystemEvent(int, String) function), which will return a RecvEventAddRemove structure whenever any client, including the one making the change, successfully adds or removes an AI controlled object.

This function should be used for fixed-wing aircraft flying between airports on land. There is no internal AI pilot for helicopters, gliders or hot-air balloons. In order to add a helicopte, glider or balloon not controlled by the user, the SimConnect client must implement full control of the aircraft. Set up these objects with a call to aICreateSimulatedObject(String, InitPosition, int).

For float-planes the recommended procedure is to control them using waypoints, and not the ATC system, as there is no concept of a "parking space" after a water landing. So, the waypoints of the route of the float-plane should include the route that it should follow before take off and after landing. For all these cases of controlling aircraft using the client, or using waypoints, set up the object using the aICreateNonATCAircraft(String, String, InitPosition, int) call.

Parameters:
containerTitle - tring containing the container title. The container title is case-sensitive and can found in the aircraft.cfg file for example: title=Airbus A321, title= Aircreation582SL, or title=Boeing 737-800.
tailNumber - string containing the tail number. This should have a maximum of 12 characters.
flightNumber - Integer containing the flight number. There is no specific maximum length of this number. Any negative number indicates that there is no flight number.
flightPlanPath - string containing the path to the flight plan file. Flight plans have the extension .pln, but no need to enter an extension here. The easiest way to create flight plans is to create them from within Flight Simulator itself, and then save them off for use with the AI controlled aircraft. There is no need to enter the full path to the file (just enter the filename) if the flight plan is in the default Flight Simulator X Files directory.
flightPlanPosition - Double floating point number containing the flight plan position. The number before the point contains the waypoint index, and the number afterwards how far along the route to the next waypoint the aircraft is to be positioned. The first waypoint index is 0. For example, 0.0 indicates that the aircraft has not started on the flight plan, 2.5 would indicate the aircraft is to be initialized halfway between the third and fourth waypoints (which would have indexes 2 and 3). The waypoints are those recorded in the flight plan, which may just be two airports, and do not include any taxiway points on the ground. Also there is a threshold that will ignore requests to have an aircraft taxiing or taking off, or landing. So set the value after the point to ensure the aircraft will be in level flight
touchAndGo - True indicating that landings should be touch and go, and not full stop landings.
dataRequestID - Specifies the client defined request ID.
Throws:
java.io.IOException

aICreateNonATCAircraft

public void aICreateNonATCAircraft(java.lang.String containerTitle,
                                   java.lang.String tailNumber,
                                   InitPosition initPos,
                                   int dataRequestID)
                            throws java.io.IOException

tailNumber - string containing the tail number. This should have a maximum of 12 characters.
initPos - Specifies the initial position, using a InitPosition structure.
dataRequestID - Specifies the client defined request ID.
Throws:

aIReleaseControl

public void aIReleaseControl(int objectID,
                             int dataRequestID)
                      throws java.io.IOException
The aIReleaseControl function is used to clear the AI control of a simulated object, typically an aircraft, in order for it to be controlled by a SimConnect client.

This function should be used to transfer the control of an aircraft, or other object, from the AI system to the SimConnect client. If this is not done the AI system and client may fight each other with unpredictable results.

The object ID can be obtained in a number of ways, refer to the requestDataOnSimObject(int, int, int, SimConnectPeriod) call, and also the use of the RecvAssignedObjectID structure.

Parameters:
objectID - Specifies the server defined object ID.
dataRequestID - Specifies the client defined request ID.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
aICreateEnrouteATCAircraft(String, String, int, String, double, boolean, int), aICreateParkedATCAircraft(String, String, String, int), aICreateNonATCAircraft(String, String, InitPosition, int), aICreateSimulatedObject(String, InitPosition, int), aISetAircraftFlightPlan(int, String, int)

executeMissionAction

public void executeMissionAction(byte[] guidInstanceId)
                          throws java.io.IOException
The function is used to execute the mission action specified by a GUID.

The GUID must be exactly 16 bytes long

A mission is specified in an xml file (see the Mission Creation documentation). In order to use SimConnect_ExecuteMissionAction, typically there should be at least one custom action within the mission xml file. The custom action will initiate the sending of a notification to the SimConnect client, and the client can then both do some processing of its own and run, by calling executeMissionAction(byte[]), one or more actions (spoken text, for example) that are defined within the xml file.

Parameters:
guidInstanceId - GUID of the Mission Action. The GUID should be found in the associated mission xml file.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
java.lang.IllegalAccessException - if GUID is not 16 bytes long

completeCustomMissionAction

public void completeCustomMissionAction(byte[] guidInstanceId)
                                 throws java.io.IOException
The completeCustomMissionAction function is used to complete the mission action specified by a GUID.

The GUID must be exactly 16 bytes long

A mission is specified in an xml file (see the Mission Creation documentation). A custom action is defined within this xml file, and will look similar to the following: 


Any string goes here!
True
Custom actions provide a mechanism to add complex processing to the basically data-driven mission system within Flight Simulator.

The custom action would typically be triggered from within the mission xml file (a trigger referencing the GUID of the custom action), though it could be called from within the SimConnect client with a call to executeMissionAction(byte[]). It is only necessary to call completeCustomMissionAction(byte[]) if the WaitForCompletion value is set to True.

If the client calls executeMissionAction(byte[]) from within the code for a custom action, and it is important that this action completes before any other actions are started (that is, WaifForCompletion is True) then a second custom action should be defined that calls completeCustomMissionAction(byte[]) after that action is complete, and with the GUID of the first custom action as its parameter. The working sample shows this process.

In order to received notifications that a custom action is to be executed, the SimConnect client should use the subscribeToSystemEvent(int, String) call with the SystemEventName parameter set to "CustomMissionActionExecuted". This will result in the GUID of the custom action, and the PayLoadString, being sent to the client in a RecvCustomAction structure.

If a mission requires additional processing on its completion the SimConnect client should use the subscribeToSystemEvent(int, String) call with the SystemEventName parameter set to "MissionCompleted".

Parameters:
guidInstanceId - GUID of the Mission Action. The GUID should be found in the associated mission xml file.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
java.lang.IllegalAccessException - if GUID is not 16 bytes long

getLastSentPacketID

public int getLastSentPacketID()
returns the ID of the last packet sent to the SimConnect server.

This function should be used in conjunction with returned structures of type RecvException to help pinpoint errors (exceptions) returned by the server. This is done by matching the send ID returned with the exception, with the number returned by this function and stored appropriately. This function is primarily intended to be used while debugging and testing the client application, rather than in a final retail build.

requestResponseTimes

public float[] requestResponseTimes(int nCount)
                             throws java.io.IOException
The requestResponseTimes function is used to provide some data on the performance of the client-server connection.

Parameters:
nCount - Integer containing the number of elements in the array of floats. This should be set to five for the full range of timings, but can be less if only the first few are of interest. There is no point creating an array of greater than five floats.
Returns:
An array of nCount floats, containing the times. The five elements will contain the following: 0 - total round trip time, 1 - time from the request till the packet is sent, 2 - time from the request till the packet is received by the server, 3 - time from the request till the response is made by the server, 4 - time from the server response to the client receives the packet.
Throws:
java.io.IOException

cameraSetRelative6DOF

public void cameraSetRelative6DOF(float deltaX,
                                  float deltaY,
                                  float deltaZ,
                                  float pitchDeg,
                                  float bankDeg,
                                  float headingDeg)
                           throws java.io.IOException
The cameraSetRelative6DOF function is used to adjust the user's aircraft view camera.

Any one of the six parameters can be set to SimConnectConstants.CAMERA_IGNORE_FIELD which indicates that the value for the camera should be taken unmodified from the reference point.

Parameters:
deltaX - Float containing the delta in the x-axis from the eyepoint reference point. See the [views] section of the Aircraft Configuration Files document for a description of the eyepoint.
deltaY - Float containing the delta in the y-axis from the eyepoint reference point.
deltaZ - Float containing the delta in the z-axis from the eyepoint reference point.
pitchDeg - Float containing the pitch in degrees (rotation about the x axis). A postive value points the nose down, a negative value up. The range of allowable values is +90 to -90 degrees.
bankDeg - Float containing the bank angle in degrees (rotation about the z axis). The range of allowable values is +180 to -180 degrees.
headingDeg - Float containing the heading in degrees (rotation about the y axis). A positive value rotates the view right, a negative value left. If the user is viewing the 2D cockpit, the view will change to the Virtual Cockpit 3D view if the angle exceeds 45 degrees from the view ahead. The Virtual Cockpit view will change back to the 2D cockpit view if the heading angle drops below 45 degrees. The range of allowable values is +180 to -180 degrees.
Throws:
java.io.IOException

menuAddItem

public void menuAddItem(java.lang.String menuItem,
                        int clientMenuEventID,
                        int data)
                 throws java.io.IOException
The menuAddItem function is used to add a menu item, associated with a client event.

The menu item will be added to the Add-ons menu. The Add-ons menu will only appear in Flight imulator if there is at least one menu entry. Sub-menu items can be associated with this menu item, see menuAddSubItem(int, String, int, int). If the text for the menu item should change, then remove the menu item first before adding the menu item with the correct text (see menuDeleteItem(int)).

Parameters:
menuItem - string containing the text for the menu item.
clientMenuEventID - specifies the client defined event ID, that is to be transmitted when the menu item is selected (in the RecvEvent.getEventID() parameter of the RecvEvent structure).
data - Contains a data value that the client can specifiy for its own use ( it will be returned in the dwData parameter of the RecvEvent structure
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
menuDeleteItem(int), menuDeleteSubItem(int, int)

                    throws java.io.IOException

menuAddSubItem

public void menuAddSubItem(int clientMenuEventID,
                           java.lang.String menuItem,
                           int clientSubMenuEventID,
                           int data)
                    throws java.io.IOException
The menuAddSubItem function is used to add a sub-menu item, associated with a client event.

A maximum of 16 sub-menu items may be added to any one main menu item. Sub-menu items are always added to the end of the sub-menu item list. An exception, SimConnectException.TOO_MANY_OBJECTS, will be returned if an attempt is made to add more than 16 sub-menu items.

Parameters:
clientMenuEventID - Specifies the client defined menu event ID. This is the ID of the menu item that this item should be added to
menuItem - string containing the text for the sub-menu item.
clientSubMenuEventID - specifies the client defined sub-menu ID, that is to be transmitted when the menu item is selected (in the RecvEvent.getEventID() parameter of the RecvEvent structure). This ID must be unique across all sub-menu items for the client.
data - Contains a data value that the client can specifiy for its own use ( it will be returned in the dwData parameter of the RecvEvent structure
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
menuAddItem(String, int, int), menuDeleteItem(int), menuDeleteSubItem(int, int)

                           java.lang.Enum clientSubMenuEventID,
                           int data)

mapClientDataNameToID

public void mapClientDataNameToID(java.lang.String clientDataName,
                                  int clientDataID)
                           throws java.io.IOException
The mapClientDataNameToID method is used to asscociate an ID with a named client data area.

This function should be called once for each client data area: the client setting up the data should call it just before a call to SimConnect_CreateClientData, and the clients requesting the data should call it before any calls to requestClientData(int, int, int, int, int) are made. The name given to a client data area must be unique, however by mapping an ID number to the name, calls to the functions to set and request the data are made more efficient.

Parameters:
clientDataName - string containing the client data area name. This is the name that another client will use to specify the data area. The name is not case-sensitive.
clientDataID - A unique ID for the client data area, specified by the client.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
addToClientDataDefinition(int, int, int, int), clearClientDataDefinition(int), createClientData(int, int, boolean), setClientData(int, int, int, int, int, byte[]), requestClientData(int, int, int, int, int)

mapClientDataNameToID

public void mapClientDataNameToID(java.lang.String clientDataName,
                                  java.lang.Enum clientDataID)
                           throws java.io.IOException
The mapClientDataNameToID method is used to asscociate an ID with a named client data area.

The name given to a client data area must be unique, however by mapping an ID number to the name, calls to the functions to set and request the data are made more efficient.

Parameters:

createClientData

public void createClientData(int clientDataID,
                             int size,
                             boolean readOnly)
                      throws java.io.IOException
The createClientData function is used to request the creation of a reserved data area for this client.

Use this function, along with the other client data functions, to reserve an area of memory for client data on the server, that other clients can have read (or read and write) access to. Specify the contents of the data area with the addToClientDataDefinition(int, int, int, int) call, and set the actual values with a call to setClientData(int, int, int, int, int, byte[]). Other clients can receive the data with a call to requestClientData(int, int, int, int, int).

One client area can be referenced by any number of client data definitions. Typically the name of the client area, and the data definitions, should be published appropriately so other clients can be written to use them. Care should be taken to give the area a unique name.

Parameters:
clientDataID - ID of the client data area. Before calling this function, call mapClientDataNameToID(String, int) to map an ID to a unique client area name.
size - the size of the data area in bytes.
readOnly - Specify this flag if the data area can only be written to by this client (the client creating the data area). By default other clients can write to this data area.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
addToClientDataDefinition(int, int, int, int), clearClientDataDefinition(int), mapClientDataNameToID(String, int), setClientData(int, int, int, int, int, byte[]), requestClientData(int, int, int, int, int)

createClientData

public void createClientData(java.lang.Enum clientDataID,
                             int size,
                             boolean readOnly)
                      throws java.io.IOException
